item.title: UpdateR package: update R version with a function (on MAC OSX)
item.description: I personally really appreciate the InstallR package from Tal galilli, since it lets you install a great number of tools needed for working with R just running a function. Among these functions one of my favourite¬†is the updateR()* function which checks for new versions of R language and in case of positive response installs it on your machine. item.title: Best Practices for Scientific Computing
item.description: I reproduce here below principles from the amazing paper Best Practices for Scientific Computing, published on 2012 by a group of US and UK professors. The main purpose of the paper is to “teach” good programming habits shared from professional developers to people that weren’t born developer, and became developers just for professional purposes. Scientists spend an increasing amount of time building and using software. However, most scientists are never taught how to do this efficiently Best Practices for Scientific Computing Write programs for people, not computers.

item.title: excel right() function in R
item.description: as part of the** excel functions in R,** I have developed this custom function, reproducing the excel right() function in th R language. Feel free to copy and use it. [code language=“r”] right = function (string, char){ substr(string,nchar(string)-(char-1),nchar(string))} [/code] you can find other function in the Excel functions in R post.

item.title: Answering to Ben ( functions comparison in R)

item.title: How to Visualize Entertainment Expenditures on a Bubble Chart
item.description: I’ve been recently asked to analyze some Board entertainment expenditures in order to acquire sufficient assurance about their nature and responsible. In response to that request I have developed a¬†little Shiny app with an interesting reactive Bubble chart. The plot, made using ggplot2 package, is composed by: a categorical x value, represented by the clusters identified in the expenditures population A numerical y value, representing the total amount expended Points defined by the total amount of expenditure in the given cluster for each company subject.
